data.text: An individual form of life, such as a bacterium, protist, fungus, plant, or animal, composed of a single cell or a complex of cells in which organelles or organs work together to carry out the various processes of life.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A system regarded as analogous in its structure or functions to a living body.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A body exhibiting organization and organic life; a member of the animal or vegetable kingdom; an individual composed of a number of essential and mutually dependent parts, all of which partake of a common life.
Anything that is organized or organic.

data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: An organized being; a living body, either vegetable or animal, composed of different organs or parts with functions which are separate, but mutually dependent, and essential to the life of the individual.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A discrete and complete <xref>living</xref> thing, such as <xref>animal</xref>, <xref>plant</xref>, <xref>fungus</xref> or <xref>microorganism</xref>.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: Any <xref>complex</xref> thing with properties normally associated with living things.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: a living thing that has (or can develop) the ability to act or function independently
data.attributionText: from WordNet 3.0 Copyright 2006 by Princeton University. All rights reserved.
